awd_titl_txt: A deep learning framework for high-definition prediction and interpretation of protein localization
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are molecules that perform diverse functions in various cell compartments and subcellular organelles. Aberrant localization of proteins may lead to harmful effects on cells, including poorly functional traits in plants, or disease in humans and animals. Protein localization is a complicated biological process controlled by many factors. Thus, for most proteins, their localization mechanisms are not well understood. Moreover, experimental methods for measuring the degree of protein localization are time- and labor-consuming. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop protein localization analysis methods. Current computational methods are often lacking in accuracy to quantify protein localization at the suborganelle level. In addition, most methods lack capacities to predict the effects of mutations on protein localization, or reveal target signals and provide information important for elucidating the mechanism of this process. This project will help address this gap in methos by developing an interpretable deep-learning approach and related informatics infrastructure for protein localization studies. The outcome will not only improve the protein localization prediction accuracy and resolution, but also shed light on localization mechanisms. Furthermore, the deep-learning framework can be applied to several other bioinformatics problems, such as mRNA localization prediction, enzyme classification and active site prediction, and protein function prediction. The project will also provide training and research experience in machine learning and real-world software development for various students, especially underrepresented minorities. Virtual workshops and community-wide competitions will be hosted annually to provide machine learning training for students with different backgrounds.

The project will develop a deep-learning framework that incorporates a sequence-based neural network and graph neural network for suborganellar protein localization prediction, together with applications of machine-learning attention mechanisms. The framework’s interpretability will enable studies of high-definition localization mechanisms, including potential novel targeting signal identification and prediction of mislocalization driven by mutation or regulatory alteration. In addition, the framework will be extended to study tissue-specific or cell-type-specific localization by incorporating single-cell data. An all-in-one web portal for protein localization prediction will be developed to provide a code-free environment for protein localization analysis. All the functionalities, and related data to be used and generated in this project will be provided on the platform. The web resource will also be an educational tool for AI learning and practices at various levels, such as high-school biology, together with many visualization and playground features. The prediction web services, as well as project progress and training materials will be provided at https://www.mu-loc.org/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We have made good progress covering the aims we proposed and beyond. The following are some of our key research outcomes:

1.     Protein localization online lectures on YouTube in 2024 for a broad range of audiences to introduce the background of the topic, cutting-edge techniques, and our related research.

2.     Hosted a workshop in 2023 for detailed technical discussions about the usage of the docker and APIs of our method.

3.     Organized a full-day workshop on AlphaFold in 2023. Within a few days, the workshop registration was filled up to the room capacity (50 people). The participants, mostly biology researchers and students, were very enthusiastic about learning how to use AlphaFold.

4.     Hosted a two-day virtual workshop (zoom) in 2022 on machine learning and protein localization. Around 70 researchers with different backgrounds from our university and other places attended the workshop.

5.     Gave many lectures about this project. For example, the PI gave a talk "Predicting protein localization by deep learning" at the Clubhouse group Quantum Photonics on June 28, 2023. There were many questions and very active discussions at the event.

6.     Developed a new version of the MULocDeep website at https://www.mu-loc.org/. It now provides species-specific models for protein localization prediction, and population-based sorting mechanism analysis. The upgraded MULocDeep method and webserver are published at Nucleic Acids Research. Jiang, Y. et al. MULocDeep web service for protein localization prediction and visualization at subcellular and suborganellar levels. Nucleic Acids Research 51, W343–W349 (2023).

7.     Applied a prompt-based learning framework, parameter-efficient fine-tuning for signal peptide prediction (PEFT-SP), to effectively utilize pre-trained protein language models. We published the PEFT-SP method at the RECOMB 2024 conference. Zeng, S., Wang, D., Jiang, L. & Xu, D. Prompt-Based Learning on Large Protein Language Models Improves Signal Peptide Prediction. in Research in Computational Molecular Biology (ed. Ma, J.) vol. 14758 400–405 (Springer Nature Switzerland, Cham, 2024).

8.     Expanded the PEFT-SP method with interpretation analysis and published the results at Genome Research. Zeng, S., Wang, D., Jiang, L. & Xu, D. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning on large protein language models improves signal peptide prediction. Genome Res. 34, 1445–1454 (2024).

9.     Actively maintained and added new functions into the MULocDeep webserver suite https://mu-loc.org/. Redesigned the MULocDeep webserver with a user-friendly way to access MULocDeep. We utilized high-performance computing resources and adhered to industry-level website development standards to ensure reliable services even when handling a high volume of tasks. The MULocDeep webserver has served more than 15,000 unique users in the last two years.

10.  Developed MULoc-target, a protein language model-based method for protein-targeting peptide prediction and detection. We have submitted this work to Advanced Science.

11.  We are developing a graph-based model for cell-line-specific protein localization and have made promising progress. The new method can predict the missing cell-line-specific subcellular localization for approximately 11,388 human proteins across 23 distinct cell lines from the Human Protein Atlas (HPA). We are now exploring the effects of graph alteration on localization based on the model.

 


Last Modified: 03/10/2025
Modified by: Dong Xu
por.por_txt_cntn:
We have made good progress covering the aims we proposed and beyond. The following are some of our key research outcomes:


1. Protein localization online lectures on YouTube in 2024 for a broad range of audiences to introduce the background of the topic, cutting-edge techniques, and our related research.


2. Hosted a workshop in 2023 for detailed technical discussions about the usage of the docker and APIs of our method.


3. Organized a full-day workshop on AlphaFold in 2023. Within a few days, the workshop registration was filled up to the room capacity (50 people). The participants, mostly biology researchers and students, were very enthusiastic about learning how to use AlphaFold.


4. Hosted a two-day virtual workshop (zoom) in 2022 on machine learning and protein localization. Around 70 researchers with different backgrounds from our university and other places attended the workshop.


5. Gave many lectures about this project. For example, the PI gave a talk "Predicting protein localization by deep learning" at the Clubhouse group Quantum Photonics on June 28, 2023. There were many questions and very active discussions at the event.


6. Developed a new version of the MULocDeep website at https://www.mu-loc.org/. It now provides species-specific models for protein localization prediction, and population-based sorting mechanism analysis. The upgraded MULocDeep method and webserver are published at Nucleic Acids Research. Jiang, Y. et al. MULocDeep web service for protein localization prediction and visualization at subcellular and suborganellar levels. Nucleic Acids Research 51, W343W349 (2023).


7. Applied a prompt-based learning framework, parameter-efficient fine-tuning for signal peptide prediction (PEFT-SP), to effectively utilize pre-trained protein language models. We published the PEFT-SP method at the RECOMB 2024 conference. Zeng, S., Wang, D., Jiang, L. & Xu, D. Prompt-Based Learning on Large Protein Language Models Improves Signal Peptide Prediction. in Research in Computational Molecular Biology (ed. Ma, J.) vol. 14758 400405 (Springer Nature Switzerland, Cham, 2024).


8. Expanded the PEFT-SP method with interpretation analysis and published the results at Genome Research. Zeng, S., Wang, D., Jiang, L. & Xu, D. Parameter-efficient fine-tuning on large protein language models improves signal peptide prediction. Genome Res. 34, 14451454 (2024).


9. Actively maintained and added new functions into the MULocDeep webserver suite https://mu-loc.org/. Redesigned the MULocDeep webserver with a user-friendly way to access MULocDeep. We utilized high-performance computing resources and adhered to industry-level website development standards to ensure reliable services even when handling a high volume of tasks. The MULocDeep webserver has served more than 15,000 unique users in the last two years.


10. Developed MULoc-target, a protein language model-based method for protein-targeting peptide prediction and detection. We have submitted this work to Advanced Science.


11. We are developing a graph-based model for cell-line-specific protein localization and have made promising progress. The new method can predict the missing cell-line-specific subcellular localization for approximately 11,388 human proteins across 23 distinct cell lines from the Human Protein Atlas (HPA). We are now exploring the effects of graph alteration on localization based on the model.
